medium_findings.title: False Positive: Git Command Documentation

content.value_statement: Developers spend too much time crafting commit messages. This skill automates conventional commit message generation by analyzing git diffs and creating standardized, searchable commit messages.
actual_capabilities: Analyzes staged and unstaged git diffs to determine change type
Generates conventional commit messages following semantic format
Supports all commit types: feat, fix, docs, style, refactor, perf, test, build, ci, chore, revert
Handles breaking changes with appropriate footer notation
Enforces commit message length limits and best practices
limitations: Does not push commits to remote repositories
Does not create branches or tags
Requires git repository with changes to commit

use_cases.title: Quick feature commits
use_cases.description: Automatically generate standardized commit messages when adding new features, saving time on message formatting.

use_cases.title: Team consistency
use_cases.description: Enforce consistent commit message standards across development teams with conventional commit formatting.

use_cases.title: Automated pipelines
use_cases.description: Generate changelogs and track changes systematically using conventional commit metadata.

best_practices: Review generated commit messages before confirming execution
Use the interactive staging option for complex changes spanning multiple areas
Include issue references (Closes #123, Fixes #456) when applicable
anti_patterns: Using vague commit messages like 'fix stuff' or 'updates'
Committing multiple unrelated changes in a single commit
Skipping the commit message review step for important changes

faq.question: What are conventional commits?
faq.answer: Conventional commits are a specification for writing commit messages in a standardized format. They include a type, optional scope, description, and optional body and footer. This format enables automated changelog generation and semantic versioning.

faq.question: Does this skill push to remote?
faq.answer: No, this skill only creates local commits. You will need to separately run 'git push' to send commits to your remote repository.

faq.question: Can I edit the generated message?
faq.answer: Yes, the generated message is a suggestion. You can modify any part before confirming the commit execution.

faq.question: What commit types are supported?
faq.answer: The skill supports all conventional commit types: feat, fix, docs, style, refactor, perf, test, build, ci, chore, and revert.

faq.question: How does the skill handle multi-file changes?
faq.answer: The skill analyzes all staged changes and generates a message that summarizes the primary type and scope. For complex changes, you can use interactive staging to group files logically.

faq.question: Does this work with all git hosts?
faq.answer: Yes, conventional commits are platform-agnostic. The generated messages work with GitHub, GitLab, Bitbucket, and any git hosting service.
